The use of an infographic: The claim was accompanied by an infographic that stated "Florida sends $135 billion and D.C. returns $150 billion." This visual representation was employed to support the claim and make it more persuasive.
Analysis of tax collections: The House communications director used data from the Internal Revenue Service to calculate the amount Florida sends, which was determined to be $135 billion. This analysis of tax collections was one aspect used to verify the authenticity of the claim.
Examination of federal spending data: The amount of federal spending in Florida was obtained from USASpending.gov, a website that tracks federal contracts, loans, grants, and public assistance. This data, which showed $150 billion in federal spending in Florida in fiscal year 2014, was another aspect used to verify the claim.
Expert opinions on methodology and data: Experts provided their opinions on the methodology used by the House and the data sources employed. They suggested alternative data sources and raised concerns about the accuracy and completeness of the information used. These expert opinions were considered in the evaluation of the claim's authenticity.
